marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Lady Elizabeth Brown Coffin-Greenly ( -1839) was the daughter and heiress of William Greenly of Titley Court, Herefordshire, England, and wife of Sir Isaac Coffin.

Entries convey the author's responses to current events and her daily life. She frequently related anecdotes about dignitaries and celebrities, including the Empress Josephine, King George III, Marie Antoinette, Mary Wollstonecraft, Hannah More, Charlotte Turner Smith, Sarah Siddons, Reverend Rowland Hill, Dr. Thomas Beddoes, and Abbe Augustin Barruel. Lady Coffin-Greenly commented on customs and conditions in countries to which her friends traveled, including Turkey, Ireland, and France. She also wrote of new discoveries in medicine, including vaccination and nitrous oxide; of the merchant ships known as Indiamen; of the excavation of the Roman villa in Woodchester, Gloucestershire; and of the living condition of the emigres in England. Some of the later entries were written in retrospect. In addition to diary entries, she appears to have copied letters she received from family and friends. In 1811, the author married Sir Isaac Coffin, who added her family name to his, but later relinquished it.
In 1811, the author married Sir Isaac Coffin, who added her family name to his, but later relinquished it.
Empress, consort of Napoleon I, Emperor of the French,
Queen, consort of Louis XVI, King of France,
Empress, consort of Napoleon I, Emperor of the French,
Queen, consort of Louis XVI, King of France,
Josiah Collins was an Edenton (Chowan Co.), N.C. resident.
Collection contains the will of Collins and two personal letters.
Michael Collins was a North Carolina planter.

Collection includes a letters from Collins' son at Wake Forest College, N.C. in 1845, with a list of school supplies and prices. There is an undated letter to a local newpaper on the evils of allowing slaves to come into town on Sunday to sell produce in exchange for whisley.
Nathaniel Comer (1795-1873) was a County Line (Davie Co.), N.C. resident.

Collection contains family letters of Nathaniel and Catherine Comer from relatives in Pettis Co., Mo., concerning family matters, the condition and prices of crops, the Mexican War, and journeys by Russell G. Comer to Santa Fe and Salt Lake City.
James O. Coghill was a farmer, resident of Henderson (Granville Co.), N.C., and a malitiaman.

Principally the Civil War letters of the four sons of Captain James O. Coghill, all members of the 23rd North Carolina Infantry Regiment, C.S.A., describing military activities in Virginia, Maryland and Pennsylvania; sickness in the army; and aid to the soldiers of the 23rd Regiment from their families in North Carolina. Included are frequent references to other members of the 23rd Regiment.
Resident of Amherst County, Va. Confederate captain.
Collection was originally part of the Don Preston Peters collection.
Letters Capt. Lindsey Coleman and his family, principally concerning the sale of agricultural products to the Confederate government during the Civil War.

Letters to Daniel Coffman of Greenbrier Co., Va. from family members living in Augusta, Rockingham, and Fayette counties. Letters chiefly contain news of friends and family members (births, marriages, deaths, and illnesses) and reflect strong religious beliefs.
U.S. Congressman and Senator, Confederate major general, governor of Georgia, from Troup County, Ga.

Papers of Alfred H. Colquitt and of his father, Walter Terry Colquitt, U.S. Congressman, including a letter by Walter concerning politics and the upcoming presidential election (1844), a letter by Alfred Colquitt to C.C. Jones, Jr., discussing his address on the New South, and an invitation from Alfred Colquitt to others regarding the laying of a cornerstone of Memorial Hall in Atlanta.
Pittsylvania Co., Va. resident; probably a planter.

Collection contains correspondence of Coles. Two letters are from Thomas Stanhope Bocock, U.S. representative from Va. (1847-1861). One letter is from Thomas Hamlet Averett, U.S. Representative from Va. Another letter pertains to R.T. Coles' estate, and still another discusses the sale of Coles' tobacco.
Cataloged in 1941; 1959. Description from card file.
Collection contains bills and receipts of Colby, and also a copy of "The Christian Arbitrator and Peace Record" of February, 1889.
Confederate soldier, from Carrollton (Pickens Co.), Ala.
Cataloged in 1949; Description from card file.
Civil War letters addressed to Cohen's wife and sister, describing camp life and the battles of first and second Manassas (Bull Run).
Official letters to Cohen from the Confederate Post-Office Department in Richmond, discussing routine matters such as appointments, routes, and delays in delivery.
U.S. Representative from Indiana (1855-1869); U.S. Vice-President (elected 1869).
Collection contains an 1866 political letter from Colfax, concerning the scheduling of a caucus; and a clipping, 1868, assessing Colfax's ability to serve as vice-president.
Author of prose and verse, from Scotch Plains (Union Co.), N.J.
Cataloged in 1952; Description from Guide. Originally part of the Marmaduke Floyd Collection.

Collection consists of correspondence directed to Emilie Coles largely from editors concerning her writings, which were published in newspapers and magazines. Also included are personal letters from Mary J. Porter (a "pen" friend) and others, including Helen E. Brown, Glenn Frank, Sam H. Hall, Edward D.G. and Samuel I. Prime, Charles A. Stoddard, and John H. Vincent.
U.S. Army major during the Civil War; resident of Wisconsin.
Collection consists of a letter to Colburn, from Montgomery Cunningham Meigs declining to attend the twentieth annual reunion of the Army of the Cumberland.
Director of American Association of Museums; member of executive committee of International Museums Office in Paris.

Collection consists of a letter to Coleman from zoologist, Roy Chapman Andrews, leader of the Central Asiatic Expeditions of the American Museum of Natural History. Andrews, in China, wrote about the destruction of Chinese antiquities, the "robber generals," and the embargo on the exportation of museum specimens.
